S5.T1.caption: Table 1: Comparison between PDC-FRS and baselines. “Aug” is short for data augmentation and “CL” is abbreviated for contrastive learning.
S5.T1.table:
ML AZ
Recall@20 NDCG@20 Recall@20 NDCG@20
FCF 0.01286 0.02142 0.00724 0.00326
FedMF 0.01420 0.02273 0.00763 0.00338
FedNCF 0.01529 0.02355 0.00875 0.00385
FedNCF+Aug 0.01580 0.02400 0.01341 0.00670
FedNCF+CL 0.01547 0.02377 0.00910 0.00368
FedNCF+Aug+CL (PDC-FRS) 0.01679 0.02557 0.01387 0.00663
references:
Table 1 presents the comparison results of PDC-FRS with baselines on the ML and AZ datasets. Overall, PDC-FRS achieves superior performance among these baselines across most metrics on both datasets. By comparing FedNCF with FedNCF+Aug and FedNCF+CL, we observe that incorporating data contributions through either our proposed augmentation method or the contrastive learning approach enhances the base FedRec performance. Furthermore, the influence of data augmentation is relatively better than that of contrastive learning, indicating that clients in FedRec suffer from a severe data scarcity problem. Finally, the combination of augmentation and contrastive learning, as implemented in PDC-FRS, further improves performance, showcasing its effectiveness. Specifically, PDC-FRS improves FedNCF’s Recall@20 scores from <math alttext="0.0152" class="ltx_Math" display="inline" id="S5.SS5.p1.1.m1.1">

bold_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a italic_u italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to augment clients’ local datasets is an effective way to leverage users’ noisy data contributions, as demonstrated in Table 1.
In this subsection, we further investigate the influence of the augmented dataset size, <math alttext="\alpha" class="ltx_Math" display="inline" id="S5.SS7.p1.2.m2.1">
  <semantics id="S5.SS7.p1.2.m2.1a">
    <mi id="S5.SS7.p1.2.m2.1.1" xref="S5.SS7.p1.2.m2.1.1.cmml">α</mi>
    <annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="S5.SS7.p1.2.m2.1b">
      <ci id="S5.SS7.p1.2.m2.1.1.cmml" xref="S5.SS7.p1.2.m2.1.1">𝛼</ci>
    </annotation-xml>
    <annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="S5.SS7.p1.2.m2.1c">\alpha</annotation>
    <annotation encoding="application/x-llamapun" id="S5.SS7.p1.2.m2.1d">italic_α</annotation>
  </semantics>
</math>, on model performance.
As depicted in Figure 
<semantics id="S5.SS7.p1.2.m2.1a">
  <mi id="S5.SS7.p1.2.m2.1.1" xref="S5.SS7.p1.2.m2.1.1.cmml">α</mi>

α<annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="S5.SS7.p1.2.m2.1b">
  <ci id="S5.SS7.p1.2.m2.1.1.cmml" xref="S5.SS7.p1.2.m2.1.1">𝛼</ci>

<ci id="S5.SS7.p1.2.m2.1.1.cmml" xref="S5.SS7.p1.2.m2.1.1">𝛼</ci>

italic_α, on model performance.
As depicted in Figure 4, we explore augmented dataset sizes ranging from <math alttext="5" class="ltx_Math" display="inline" id="S5.SS7.p1.3.m3.1">
  <semantics id="S5.SS7.p1.3.m3.1a">
    <mn id="S5.SS7.p1.3.m3.1.1" xref="S5.SS7.p1.3.m3.1.1.cmml">5</mn>
    <annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="S5.SS7.p1.3.m3.1b">
      <cn id="S5.SS7.p1.3.m3.1.1.cmml" type="integer" xref="S5.SS7.p1.3.m3.1.1">5</cn>
    </annotation-xml>
    <annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="S5.SS7.p1.3.m3.1c">5</annotation>
    <annotation encoding="application/x-llamapun" id="S5.SS7.p1.3.m3.1d">5</annotation>
  </semantics>
</math> to 
<semantics id="S5.SS7.p1.3.m3.1a">
  <mn id="S5.SS7.p1.3.m3.1.1" xref="S5.SS7.p1.3.m3.1.1.cmml">5</mn>
  <annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="S5.SS7.p1.3.m3.1b">
    <cn id="S5.SS7.p1.3.m3.1.1.cmml" type="integer" xref="S5.SS7.p1.3.m3.1.1">5</cn>
  </annotation-xml>
  <annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="S5.SS7.p1.3.m3.1c">5</annotation>
  <annotation encoding="application/x-llamapun" id="S5.SS7.p1.3.m3.1d">5</annotation>
</semantics>
<mn id="S5.SS7.p1.3.m3.1.1" xref="S5.SS7.p1.3.m3.1.1.cmml">5</mn>
5<annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="S5.SS7.p1.3.m3.1b">
  <cn id="S5.SS7.p1.3.m3.1.1.cmml" type="integer" xref="S5.SS7.p1.3.m3.1.1">5</cn>
</annotation-xml>
<cn id="S5.SS7.p1.3.m3.1.1.cmml" type="integer" xref="S5.SS7.p1.3.m3.1.1">5</cn>
5<annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="S5.SS7.p1.3.m3.1c">5</annotation>
5<annotation encoding="application/x-llamapun" id="S5.SS7.p1.3.m3.1d">5</annotation>
5 to <math alttext="60" class="ltx_Math" display="inline" id="S5.SS7.p1.4.m4.1">
  <semantics id="S5.SS7.p1.4.m4.1a">
    <mn id="S5.SS7.p1.4.m4.1.1" xref="S5.SS7.p1.4.m4.1.1.cmml">60</mn>
    <annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="S5.SS7.p1.4.m4.1b">
      <cn id="S5.SS7.p1.4.m4.1.1.cmml" type="integer" xref="S5.SS7.p1.4.m4.1.1">60</cn>
    </annotation-xml>
    <annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="S5.SS7.p1.4.m4.1c">60</annotation>
    <annotation encoding="application/x-llamapun" id="S5.SS7.p1.4.m4.1d">60</annotation>
  </semantics>
</math> on the ML and AZ datasets. The performance trends on these two datasets are similar: model performance increases to a peak and then decreases as the augmented dataset size continues to grow. This indicates that an appropriate amount of data augmentation can improve model performance, however, if the augmentation set becomes too large, it will impede the model’s ability to learn from the original dataset.
<semantics id="S5.SS7.p1.4.m4.1a">

</annotation-xml>
<cn id="S5.SS7.p1.4.m4.1.1.cmml" type="integer" xref="S5.SS7.p1.4.m4.1.1">60</cn>

60<annotation encoding="application/x-llamapun" id="S5.SS7.p1.4.m4.1d">60</annotation>
60 on the ML and AZ datasets. The performance trends on these two datasets are similar: model performance increases to a peak and then decreases as the augmented dataset size continues to grow. This indicates that an appropriate amount of data augmentation can improve model performance, however, if the augmentation set becomes too large, it will impede the model’s ability to learn from the original dataset.
